boardgame.name: Tempus
Tempvs
boardgame.description: User review_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;Set up:_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;The game contains twelve map tiles. Each map tile is made of one hexagon surrounded by six hexagons. Each tile will have a mixture of any or all of five types of terrain: grasslands, farmlands, mountains, woods, and hills. Each player gets a Player Aid card, selects a color of people tokens and places the era cube of the matching color on The Era Starting Box on the Progress Column part of the game board. A starting player is selected. Some tiles are placed contiguously on the game board (the number of tiles depends on the number of players) one at a time in turn order. Each player, in turn, places three of their people tokens on the game board contiguously. The game is now ready to begin._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;Game play:_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;Players should note which terrain will be worth Progress Points at the end of the era. Progress Points are the number of hexes occupied of the scoring terrain by one_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;rsquo;s token plus the number of city tiles plus the value of all eligible Idea Cards. The player or players with the most Progress Points will advance to the new era and get an advantage over the other players._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;In turn, a player may:_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;- Move people_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;- Have babies (increase the number of people tokens on the game board)_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;- Have a fight (initiate the diceless combat system against another player)_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;- Have an idea (draw chance cards)_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;- Build a city (replace people tokens with a city tile)_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;After all the players have used all of their turns the era has ended. If this not the first round then all the players_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;rsquo; Era Cubes are advanced to the level of the leader(s). Progress Points are then compared and the leader(s) advance to take advantage of one_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;rsquo;s newest ability._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;The game is over after ten eras. Victory Points are the total of number of non-mountain hexagons occupied by one_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;rsquo;s tokens plus the values of one_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;rsquo;s cities plus three points for advancing to the final era. The player with most Victory Points is the winner._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;

Thank you, Jeremy, Jennifer, and Family J and J Board Games

Cafe Games (CGL1001) A civilization building game has finally been created that clocks in under two hours. Tempus plays on a modular board with an array of landscapes on each land tile to ensure a different game every session. Each turn pushes players_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039; technological advancements forward, starting from fire and ending in the modern age. Players are constantly faced with tough choices to vie for technological superiority or better positioning on the game board. This game features a rubber-banding mechanic in technological upgrading, where players catch up to the leader_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s advances at the end of every turn and shoot forward to take advantage of any new technologies that are discovered. This keeps players constantly in check, while rewarding planning for the next turn by giving an edge-up. Tempus showcases a simple diceless battle mechanic featuring a subtle fog of war with Idea cards. Each card is dual-purposed. Using a card for war means giving up extra abilities that the Idea cards can grant. Or you might just want to hold on to them to advance in technology.
